article.name: Microsoft 365 and Microsoft Defender for Cloud Apps Integration Guide for SecurityCoach
article.title: Microsoft 365 and Microsoft Defender for Cloud Apps Integration Guide for SecurityCoach
article.body:
In this article, you will learn how to integrate Microsoft 365 and Microsoft Defender for Cloud Apps, formerly Microsoft Cloud Access Security (MCAS), with SecurityCoach. Once the integration is complete, data provided by Microsoft will be available under the SecurityCoach tab of your KSAT console. This data can be viewed in SecurityCoach reports and used to create detection rules for real-time coaching campaigns.

For more information about SecurityCoach, see our SecurityCoach Product Manual. To integrate other Microsoft products with SecurityCoach, see our Setting Up Integrations articles.

Tip:SecurityCoach also supports integrating Microsoft 365 and Microsoft Defender for Cloud Apps as Splunk vendors. If your organization uses Splunk for security information and event management, we recommend integrating through Splunk instead by following our Splunk Integrations Guide for SecurityCoach.

Prerequisites

Microsoft 365

One of the following Microsoft license bundles is required to ensure a successful Microsoft 365 integration:

  • Microsoft 365 E5 with the Microsoft 365 E5 Security and Microsoft 365 E5 Compliance add-ons
  • Microsoft Enterprise Mobility with the Microsoft 365 E5 Security add-on
  • Microsoft Office 365 E5

For more information, see Microsoft’s Defender XDR licensing requirements.

Microsoft Defender for Cloud Apps

One of the following Microsoft license bundles is required to ensure a successful Microsoft Defender for Cloud Apps integration:

  • Microsoft 365 E5 with the Microsoft E5 Security add-on
  • Windows 11 Enterprise E5

For more information, see Microsoft’s Defender XDR licensing requirements.

Note:Microsoft Government Community Cloud (GCC) integrations are not supported at this time.

Set Up the Integration in Your Microsoft Azure Portal

Before you can set up the SecurityCoach integration in your KSAT console, you will need to register the SecurityCoach application, add API permissions, and create a client secret in your Microsoft Azure portal.

Important:To integrate Microsoft 365 and Microsoft MCAS with the KSAT console, you will need a unique registered application, API permission, client secret, and tenant for each product.

To jump to the article subsection for each of these steps, click the links below:

  • Register the SecurityCoach Application
  • Add API Permissions
  • Create a Client Secret

Register the SecurityCoach Application

First, you will need to register the SecurityCoach application in your Microsoft Azure portal. To register the application, follow the steps below:

  1. Log in to your Microsoft Azure portal and navigate to your Microsoft Entra ID.

  2. From the sidebar on the left side of the page, select App registrations.

  3. Click + New registration and enter a name for your application, such as “SecurityCoachAPIAccess”.

  4. Click Register.

Add API Permissions

After you have registered the SecurityCoach application, you can add API permissions. To add API permissions, follow the steps below:

  1. Log in to your Microsoft Azure portal and navigate to your Microsoft Entra ID.

  2. From the sidebar on the left side of the page, select App registrations.

  3. Select the registered application you created for Microsoft 365 or MCAS in the Register the SecurityCoach Application section of this guide. In the example below, the registered application is titled “MS-Alert”.

  4. From the sidebar on the left side of the page, select API permissions.

  5. Click + Add a permission.

  6. Select Microsoft Graph from the Microsoft APIs subtab.

  7. Click Application permissions.

  8. Click the SecurityAlert drop-down menu and select the check box next to SecurityAlert.Read.All.

  9. Click Add permissions.
  10. Click Grant admin consent for [your active directory name]. Once permission is granted, the triangle symbol on the right side of the page will change to a green check mark.

Create a Client Secret

After you have registered the SecurityCoach application and added API permissions, you can create a client secret. To create a client secret, follow the steps below:

  1. Log in to your Microsoft Azure portal and navigate to your Microsoft Entra ID.

  2. From the sidebar on the left side of the page, select App registrations and click on the registered application you added permissions to in the Add API Permissions section of this article. When you click on the registered application, the application’s overview page will display.
  3. From the sidebar on the left side of the page, select Certificates & secrets.

  4. Click + New client secret.

  5. Enter a description for the client secret and select an expiry window.

  6. Click Add. Once you click Add, the client secret Value and Expires date will display.

  7. Copy and save the client secret Value and the Expires date somewhere that you can easily access. You will need these credentials to complete the integration setup in the Set Up the Integration in Your KSAT Console section below.

Set Up the Integration in Your KSAT Console

Once you've set up the integration in your Microsoft Azure portal, you can set up the integration in your KSAT console.

Note:To complete these steps, you will need to have both your Microsoft Azure portal and your KSAT console open in your browser.

To set up the integration in your KSAT console, follow the steps below:

  1. Log in to your KSAT console and navigate to SecurityCoach > Setup.
  2. In the Available Integrations section, locate the card for the Microsoft application you want to set up.
  3. At the bottom of the card, click Configure.

  4. In a separate browser window, log in to your Microsoft Azure portal and navigate to your Microsoft Entra ID.
  5. From the Overview page, scroll down to the Tenant information section. Then, copy the Primary domain.

  6. Navigate back to your KSAT console. In the Primary Domain field, paste your Primary domain.

  7. To get your Application (Client) ID, navigate to your Microsoft Azure portal. Select App registrations and click on the registered application you created for Microsoft 365 or MCAS in the Register the SecurityCoach Application section of this article.
  8. On the application’s overview page, copy the Application (client) ID in the Essentials section at the top of the page.

  9. Navigate back to your KSAT console. In the Application (Client) ID field, paste your Application (client) ID.

  10. In the Client Secret Value field, enter the Value from the client secret that you created in the Create a Client Secret section above.

  11. In the Token Expiration Date field, select the Expires date for the client secret that you created in the Create a Client Secret section above.

  12. To finish setting up the integration, click Connect.

Once you’ve successfully authorized this integration, you can manage detection rules for Microsoft 365 or MCAS on the Detection Rules subtab of SecurityCoach. For a full list of available system detection rules for this vendor, see our Which Detection Rules Can I Use with My Vendors? article.

images.alt:
A screenshot displays the navigation sidebar of the Microsoft Azure portal interface.

**Sidebar Content (Top to Bottom):**

1.  **Menu Icon** (Hamburger icon).
2.  **Create a resource** (plus icon).
3.  **Home** (house icon).
4.  **Dashboard** (chart icon).
5.  **All services** (list icon).
6.  **FAVORITES** (Section header with a star icon).
7.  **All resources** (grid icon).
8.  **Resource groups** (cube icon).
9.  **App Services** (blue sphere icon).
10. **Function App** (lightning bolt icon).
11. **SQL databases** (SQL icon).
12. **Azure Cosmos DB** (blue/green galaxy icon).
13. **Virtual machines** (monitor icon).
14. **Load balancers** (green diamond icon).
15. **Storage accounts** (blue/green container icon).
16. **Virtual networks** (two arrows/brackets icon).
17. **Azure Active Directory** (Blue diamond icon, highlighted with an orange border, indicating selection or focus).
18. **Monitor** (dial gauge icon).
19. **Advisor** (cloud/lightbulb icon).
20. **Security Center** (green shield/lock icon).
21. **Cost Management + Billing** (green dollar sign icon).
22. **Help + support** (headset icon).

**Contextual View (Right Panel Snippets):**

The visible edge of the main content pane shows typical Azure dashboard elements, including a search bar labeled "Search resourc," a section header "ure services," and navigational links like "Create a resource," "Free Trial," "Subscriptions," and "Microsoft Learn."
images.context: nd navigate to your Microsoft Entra ID.

This image displays a segment of the navigation pane within the Azure Portal interface, specifically focused on an Azure Active Directory (Azure AD) blade.

**Header Context:**
The top section indicates the current location: `Home > secadvbot | Overview`. Below the main title, the context is specified as `Azure Active Directory`.

**Navigation Menu (Blade):**
The left navigation pane lists various management categories and links.

*   **Top Links (Uncategorized):**
    *   Overview (Highlighted, suggesting the current page)
    *   Getting started
    *   Preview features
    *   Diagnose and solve problems

*   **"Manage" Category:**

**Focus Element:**
The menu item **"App registrations"** is explicitly highlighted with an orange rectangular border, indicating it is the target element for selection or emphasis.
images.context: side of the page, select App registrations.

images.alt:
This screenshot displays a partial view of a management console UI, likely related to identity management or application registration (e.g., Azure Active Directory).

**Left Navigation Blade:**
The navigation pane features categorized links:
*   **Top Links:** Overview, Getting started, Preview features, Diagnose and solve problems.
*   **Manage Section Header:** Followed by the link Users (with an accompanying icon).

**Main Content Header/Action Bar:**
*   A primary action button, highlighted with an orange border, is labeled **"+ New registration."**
*   Other actions visible include links for **Endpoints** (with a globe icon) and **Troubleshoot** (with a wrench icon).

**Informational Banners:**
The main content area includes two informational (blue alert) boxes:
1.  A notification prompting users to **"Try out the new App registrations search preview!"**
2.  A service update notification stating: **"Starting June 30th, 2020 we will no longer add any new [security] updates but we will no longer provide feature updates."** (The text implies a cutoff date for feature support).

**Content Filters/Tabs:**
At the bottom of the visible area, tabs for filtering application lists are present, including **All applications** and the bolded, currently selected tab, **Owned applications.**
images.context: name for your application, such as “SecurityCoachAPIAccess”.

images.alt:
This image captures the "Register an application" configuration screen within the Microsoft Azure portal.

**Context and Navigation:**
*   The platform is identified by the "Microsoft Azure" header.
*   The breadcrumb navigation is displayed as `Home > secadvbot > Register an application`.
*   The page title is **Register an application**.

**Configuration Elements:**

1.  **Name (Required Field):**
    *   The input field is labeled "\* Name" and describes the entry as "The user-facing display name for this application."
    *   The current value entered is `SecurityCoachAPIAccess`.

2.  **Supported Account Types (Radio Button Group):**
    *   This section determines who can use the application or access the API.
    *   The first option is currently **selected**: "Accounts in this organizational directory only (secadvbot only - Single tenant)."
    *   Other options include multi-tenant configurations and those supporting personal Microsoft accounts. A "Help me choose..." link is provided below the options.

3.  **Redirect URI (Optional):**
    *   This section includes descriptive text regarding the return of the authentication response.
    *   Two input controls are provided: a dropdown titled "Select a platform" and an adjacent text input field with the placeholder `e.g. https://example.com/auth`.

**Action and Policy:**
*   A policy acknowledgement link reads: "By proceeding, you agree to the Microsoft Platform Policies."
*   The primary action button, located at the bottom of the page, is the blue, solid **Register** button.

images.alt:
This image is a screenshot of the Microsoft Azure portal, specifically displaying the **App registrations** blade within an Azure Active Directory context named `secadvbot`.

**Header and Navigation:**
*   **Top Bar:** Displays "Microsoft Azure" and a search bar labeled "Search resources, services, and docs (G+/)". The user context shows the tenant/user as `secadvbot.onmic...`.
*   **Breadcrumb:** `Home > secadvbot`.
*   **Title:** `secadvbot | App registrations` under the subtitle `Azure Active Directory`.

**Left Navigation Pane (Highlighted Section):**
The left pane shows management links. The **App registrations** link, under the "Manage" heading, is currently highlighted/selected. Other visible links include Users, Groups, Enterprise applications, and Identity Governance.

**Main Content Area:**
*   **Action Bar:** Contains controls: `+ New registration`, `Endpoints`, `Troubleshooting`, `Refresh`, `Download`, `Preview features`, and `Got feedback?`.
*   **Information Banner:** A blue informational box warns: "Starting June 30th, 2020, we will no longer add any new features to Azure Active Directory Authentication Library (ADAL) and Azure AD Graph. We will continue to provide technical support and security updates but we will no longer provide feature updates. Applications will need to be upgraded to Microsoft Authentication Library (MSAL) and Microsoft Graph. [Learn more]".
*   **Tabbed View:** Displays three tabs: `All applications`, **`Owned applications`** (selected), and `Deleted applications`.
*   **Filter/Search Bar:** A text input field reads: "Start typing a display name or application (client) ID to filter these r..." followed by an **`+ Add filters`** button.
*   **Results Summary:** `8 applications found`.

**Application List (Table):**
The primary content is a table listing owned applications.
*   **Columns:** `Display name`, `Application (client) ID` (masked/redacted), `Created on`, and `Certificates & secrets`.
*   **Data Example:** The table shows five rows of application data.
    *   The fifth visible row is highlighted (appears orange/selected) and displays the Display Name **`MS-Alert`**.
    *   The `Created on` dates vary (e.g., 3/25/2022, 4/30/2021).
    *   The `Certificates & secrets` column typically shows **`Current`** (with a green checkmark) indicating valid certificates, or a dash for applications without secrets.

images.alt:
This image displays the Microsoft Azure portal interface, specifically the configuration page for an application registration.

**Context and Navigation:**

*   **Platform:** Microsoft Azure.
*   **Breadcrumbs:** `Home > secadvbot > MS-Alert`.
*   **Page Title:** `MS-Alert | API permissions`.

**Left Navigation Menu (Sidebar):**

The left sidebar provides application configuration links, organized into functional groups:

1.  **Search:** A search box labeled `Search (Ctrl+/)` is present at the top of the navigation pane.
2.  **Top-level items:** `Overview`, `Quickstart`, `Integration assistant`.
3.  **Manage:** This section includes configuration links:
    *   `Branding & properties`
    *   `Authentication`
    *   `Certificates & secrets`
    *   `Token configuration`
    *   **`API permissions` (Selected):** This link is highlighted with an orange border, indicating the current page view.
    *   `Expose an API`
    *   `App roles`
    *   `Owners`
    *   `Roles and administrators`
    *   `Manifest`
4.  **Support + Troubleshooting:** This section begins with the link `Troubleshooting`.

**Content Pane (Right Side - Partially Visible):**

The content pane displays elements related to API permissions configuration:

*   A `Refresh` control (circular arrow icon).
*   Alert boxes (e.g., a warning box with an exclamation triangle and the text `Starti...`, and an information box).
*   A section title beginning with `Configured...`.
*   An action button/link labeled `+ Add a p...` (indicating the ability to add a new permission).
*   A list structure showing defined permissions under categories like `Microsoft...` and `Windows...`, including specific delegated permissions such as `User.Re...` and `Alert.R...`.
images.context: eft side of the page, select API permissions.

images.alt:
This screen capture displays the **API permissions** configuration blade within the Microsoft Azure portal for the application registration **SecurityAdvisorAPIAccess**.

**Context and Navigation:**
*   The primary interface title is `SecurityAdvisorAPIAccess | API permissions`.
*   The left navigation panel shows **API permissions** highlighted under the **Manage** section.

**Notices:**
*   An orange warning banner alerts the user that starting November 9th, 2020, end users will no longer be able to grant consent to newly registered multitenant apps without verified publishers (prompting to Add MPN ID).
*   A blue informational banner explains that the "Admin consent required" column shows the default organizational value, which may be customized.

**Actions and Configuration:**
*   The main action available is the prominent button **+ Add a permission** (outlined).
*   Adjacent to this is the option: `Grant admin consent for secadvbot`.

**Configured Permissions Table:**
The table lists existing permissions under the `Configured permissions` heading, structured by API:
*   **API:** Microsoft Graph (1)
*   **Permissions Name:** User.Read
*   **Type:** Delegated
*   **Description:** Sign in and read user profile
*   **Admin consent req...:** No

**Footer:**
A note directs users to `Enterprise applications` for viewing and managing permissions and user consent.
images.context:
>

Click + Add a permission.

images.alt:
The image displays a section of a UI workflow titled "**Request API permissions**."

**UI Context and Navigation:**
*   The primary instruction is "**Select an API**."
*   Three pivot tabs are present: "**Microsoft APIs**" (currently selected, indicated by an underline), "**APIs my organization uses**," and "**My APIs**."
*   A secondary heading, "**Commonly used Microsoft APIs**," identifies the content below.

**Selected API Listing:**
*   The featured item is a listing for **Microsoft Graph**, accompanied by its blue geometric icon.
*   The API description reads: "Take advantage of the tremendous amount of data in Office 365, Enterprise Mobility + Security, and Windows 10. Access Azure AD, Excel, Intune, Outlook/Exchange, OneDrive, OneNote, SharePoint, Planner, and more through a single endpoint."
images.context: raph from the Microsoft APIs subtab.

images.alt:
This configuration panel, titled "Request API permissions," displays options for defining the required access type for an application targeting the **Microsoft Graph** API.

**Key UI Elements and Text:**

1.  **Header:** "Request API permissions."
2.  **Target API:** "Microsoft Graph" is identified, including its URL (`https://graph.microsoft.com/`) and a link to documentation ("Docs").
3.  **Prompt:** "What type of permissions does your application require?"
4.  **Permission Models (Two options):**
    *   **Delegated permissions:** "Your application needs to access the API as the signed-in user." (Unselected/Standard box)
    *   **Application permissions:** "Your application runs as a background service or daemon without a signed-in user." (Visually highlighted with an orange border, indicating selection or focus).
images.context:
i>
Click Application permissions.

images.alt:
This image displays a configuration screen for defining permissions, presented in a list format with two main columns: **Permission** and **Admin consent required**.

The permissions are grouped hierarchically using collapsible categories, indicated by Chevron icons. Several categories are listed, including:

1.  **PartnerSecurity** (Collapsed)
2.  **Policy** (Collapsed)
3.  **SecurityActions** (Collapsed)
4.  **SecurityAlert (1)** (Expanded, indicated by a downward-pointing Chevron).

The expanded **SecurityAlert (1)** category shows two selectable permission scopes listed below it:

*   **SecurityAlert.Read.All**:
    *   Description: "Read all security alerts"
    *   Status: Selected (blue checkmark in a checkbox).
    *   Admin Consent Required: "Yes"
    *   Includes an information icon (i) next to the scope name.

*   **SecurityAlert.ReadWrite.All**:
    *   Description: "Read and write to all security alerts"
    *   Status: Unselected (empty checkbox).
    *   Admin Consent Required: "Yes"
    *   Includes an information icon (i) next to the scope name.

The list continues with the next collapsed category: **SecurityAnalyzedMessage**. The background features alternating light gray and white row shading for visual separation.
images.context: the check box next to SecurityAlert.Read.All.

images.alt:
This image displays a user interface (UI) section for managing API permissions, likely within an identity or application registration portal (e.g., Azure Active Directory).

**1. Actions and Context:**
*   **Add Permission:** An action link, indicated by a plus sign icon, labeled "Add a permission."
*   **Admin Consent:** An action button/link, indicated by a checkmark icon, labeled "Grant admin consent for secadvbot." This action is applied to the permissions listed below for the target entity "secadvbot."

**2. Data Grid Structure:**
The main content is a permissions data grid with the following column headers:
*   API / Permissions name
*   Type
*   Description
*   Admin consent requ... (Admin consent required)
*   Status
*   (Action ellipsis icon)

**3. Permissions Listed:**
All displayed permissions are grouped under an expandable section labeled **Microsoft Graph (2)**.

| API / Permissions name | Type | Description | Admin consent required | Status |
| :--- | :--- | :--- | :--- | :--- |
| **SecurityAlert.Read.All** | Application | Read all security alerts | Yes | Granted for secadvbot (Green checkmark) |
| **User.Read** | Delegated | Sign in and read user profile | No | Granted for secadvbot (Green checkmark) |

**Summary of Status:** Both the Application permission (`SecurityAlert.Read.All`) and the Delegated permission (`User.Read`) have been successfully granted for the application/principal named `secadvbot`.
images.context: mbol on the right side of the page will change to a green check mark.

images.alt:
This image displays the left navigation menu of the Microsoft Azure portal, specifically within the context of managing an Application Registration.

**Context and Breadcrumb:**
The page is identified as being within **Microsoft Azure**. The breadcrumb path shows: `Home > secadvbot > SecurityAdvisorAPIAccess`. The main header confirms the context is **SecurityAdvisorAPIAccess**, preceded by a logo resembling a looping arrow/cloud.

**Navigation Menu (Left Pane):**
The menu lists various configuration and management options for the application, starting with a search bar labeled `Search (Ctrl+/)`.

**Menu Sections and Items (Top to Bottom):**

1.  **Top Level (Uncategorized):**
    *   Overview
    *   Quickstart
    *   Integration assistant

2.  **Manage:**
    *   Branding
    *   Authentication
    *   **Certificates & secrets** (This item is highlighted with an orange border, indicating it is currently selected or being focused on.)
    *   Token configuration

3.  **API permissions:** (This section header is visually distinct, formatted similarly to a major navigation item.)
    *   Expose an API
    *   App roles
    *   Owners
    *   Roles and administrators | Pre... (Text truncated)
    *   Manifest

4.  **Support + Troubleshooting:** (Section Header)
    *   Troubleshooting
    *   New support request (Partially visible)

**Right Pane (Partial View):**
The right pane shows content related to the selected menu item. Visible fragments include:
*   A warning icon (orange triangle) next to truncated text starting with `Sta`.
*   An information icon (blue circle) next to truncated text.
*   The header `Configu...` (Configuration).
*   Text related to application permissions.
*   A button/link labeled `+ Add...`.
*   The text `API`.

**Key Focus:**
The primary focus of the image is the selected navigation item: **Certificates & secrets**, identified by a key icon and enclosed in an orange selection box.
images.context: page, select Certificates & secrets.

images.alt:
This image displays the configuration panel for **Client secrets**, used to manage application passwords for proving identity when requesting tokens.

**Key Text and UI Elements:**

1.  **Title and Context:** The section is titled "Client secrets," accompanied by a definition explaining that a client secret is "A secret string that the application uses to prove its identity when requesting a token. Also can be referred to as application password."
2.  **Action Button (Highlighted):** A primary action button, highlighted by an orange outline, is available: `+ New client secret`. The `+` symbol is a blue icon indicating an add/create function.
3.  **Table Headers:** The UI includes the column headers for listing existing client secrets: **Description**, **Expires**, **Value**, and **ID**.
4.  **Status Message:** The current state of the list is empty, indicated by the message: "No client secrets have been created for this application."
images.context:
/a>

Click + New client secret.

images.alt:
A modal dialog box titled "**Add a client secret**" is displayed.

**UI Elements and Fields:**

1.  **Description:** A label paired with a text input field. The placeholder text in the input field is "**Enter a description for this client secret**".
2.  **Expires:** A label paired with a dropdown selector. The currently selected value is "**Recommended: 6 months**".

**Action Buttons (Footer):**

*   **Add:** A primary, blue button (selected state).
*   **Cancel:** A secondary button.

The dialog also includes a standard closing control (an 'X' icon) in the top-right corner.
images.context: description for the client secret and select an expiry window.

images.alt:
This image displays a UI panel managing "Client secrets."

**Heading and Context:**
*   **Title:** "Client secrets"
*   **Descriptive Text:** "A secret string that the application uses to prove its identity when requesting a token. Also can be referred to as application password."
*   **Action Button:** A link labeled "**+ New client secret**" is present.

**Data Table:**
The panel features a table with four columns, displaying a single client secret entry:

1.  **Description:** "SecurityAdvisorAPIkey"
2.  **Expires:** "5/3/2022"
3.  **Value (Highlighted):** Partially obscured text field beginning with "0X..." followed by a masked string, ending with "...11." This field is enclosed in an orange selection box, indicating the secret value.
4.  **ID:** Partially obscured text field beginning with "53..." followed by a masked string, ending with "...81."

**Actions:**

The image displays two modular UI configuration tiles, positioned side-by-side against a white background.

1.  **Left Tile (Microsoft Cloud App Security):**
    *   **Branding:** A dark blue square icon featuring a white outline of a cloud structure connected by a horizontal line to a central circular node.
    *   **Text/Labels:** Small white text reads "Microsoft" (top right) and "Cloud App Security" (bottom center) within the icon area.
    *   **Action Button:** A full-width, solid blue button containing the centered white text: **Configure**.

2.  **Right Tile (Microsoft 365):**
    *   **Branding:** The Microsoft 365 logo (a 2x2 grid of red, green, blue, and yellow squares) positioned above the service name.
    *   **Text/Labels:** Large, centralized grey text reads: **Microsoft 365**.
    *   **Action Button:** A full-width, solid blue button containing the centered white text: **Configure**.

**Context:** The interface presents two distinct Microsoft service integration options, both utilizing an identical **Configure** call-to-action button to initiate the setup process for the respective application (Cloud App Security) or suite (Microsoft 365).

This image displays a configuration screen for a "Microsoft 365" integration within a technical application interface.

**Header and Context:**
*   The title is **Microsoft 365**.
*   A descriptive text reads: "For more information about configuring this vendor integration, see the **Microsoft 365 Integration Guide for SecurityCoach.**" The guide title is a clickable link with an external link icon.
*   In the top right, a navigation link reads: **← Back to Integrations**.

**Input Fields (Four fields arranged in two columns):**
1.  **Application (Client) ID** (Empty text box).
2.  **Client Secret Value** (Empty text box).
3.  **Primary Domain** (Empty text box, highlighted by an orange rectangular border, indicating focus or selection in the original context, but presented as a standard input field here).
4.  **Token Expiration Date** (Text box containing the pre-filled date **12/06/2025**, prefixed by a calendar icon). Beneath this field, explanatory text reads: "Default expiration 1 year from today."

**Action Buttons:**
*   A primary action button labeled **Connect** (blue text inside a bordered box).
*   A secondary action link labeled **Cancel**.

images.alt:
This image displays the Azure Portal interface for an application registration named **SecurityAdvisorAPIAccess**, specifically on the **Overview** blade (highlighted in orange on the left navigation pane).

**UI Context and Navigation:**

*   **Header:** Shows the application name: **SecurityAdvisorAPIAccess**.
*   **Action Bar:** Contains options for **Delete**, **Endpoints**, and **Preview features**.
*   **Navigation Pane (Left):**
    *   The **Overview** menu item is selected (highlighted).
    *   Other visible menu groups include Quickstart and Integration assistant, followed by the **Manage** group (Branding, Authentication, Certificates & secrets, Token configuration, API permissions, Expose an API).

**Content: Essentials Section**

The main content area features an **Essentials** section displaying key application identifiers:

| Field | Value | Notes |
| :--- | :--- | :--- |
| Display name | SecurityAdvisorAPIAccess | |
| **Application (client) ID** | Partially obscured GUID (ending in 6b) | **Highlighted in orange.** This is the primary client identifier. |
| Directory (tenant) ID | b0026544-7602-401d-b6ff-a3a12cfb80ca | |
| Object ID | 73dcee00-e598-4c66-aa7e-da4736a0d430 | |
| Supported account types | Multiple organizations | |
| Redirect URIs | Add a Redirect URI (link) | |
| Application ID URI | Add an Application ID URI (link) | |

**Informational Banners:**

Two blue informational banners are visible below the Essentials section:

1.  A welcome banner referencing the "new and improved App registrations."
2.  A critical deprecation warning stating that after June 30th, 2020, new features will no longer be added to **Azure Active Directory Authentication Library (ADAL)** and **Azure AD Graph**, and applications must be upgraded to **Microsoft Authentication Library (MSAL)** and **Microsoft Graph**.
